 Indeed, you are supposed to run precompile in production environment. Precompile does not set the environment on its own. This way you can precompile in different environments, e.g. in test to speed up integration tests. Precompiling in development is mostly for debugging.

Since there are no digests even with the URLs overridden, this looks like your environment's configuration issue, not a bootstrap-sass one.

By the way, Rails precompiles all non-CSS/JS assets by default already, so that line in application.rb is not necessary.
 Rails appends digests (hashes) if and only if `config.assets.digest` is true. It is **true** by default in production, and **false** everywhere else.

This could be because of a `//= require` instead of `@import` somewhere in Sass. Use `@import` instead so that the variables are shared across the `@import`ed files.
 @rebelwarrior If you do a precompile in development, `config.assets.digest` will be false if you've only set it to true in production. Either way, you need to make sure `config.assets.digest = true` in the environment you are running precompile in.
  Import grid modules in this order:

Grid framework mixins (columns):

``` scss
@import "bootstrap/mixins/grid-framework";
```

Grid mixins (rows, columns for default screens):

``` scss
@import "bootstrap/mixins/grid";
```

Grid classes (.row, .container, media queries):

``` scss
@import "bootstrap/grid";
```

The last 2 modules also need [screen size and grid variables](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/_variables.scss#L263-L334) set to be imported.

 There is a global variable `$list` somewhere else in Sass. It is being overwritten because a bootstrap-sass mixin defines a local variable with the same name and is then included into root. When this happens, the [current but deprecated](http://sass-lang.com/documentation/file.SASS_CHANGELOG.html#backwards_incompatibilities__must_read) Sass behaviour is to set the global `$list` to the value of the mixin's local `$list`. This is what is being worked around in the commit above.

Until the next version is out, you can change the global `$list` to something else and the warning will disappear.

 It should be `depend_on`, as there is [an open issue](https://github.com/sstephenson/sprockets/issues/557) with `depend_on_asset`.

From Sprockets documentation:

`depend_on` allows you to state a dependency on a file without including it.

This is used for caching purposes. Any changes made to the dependency file with invalidate the cache of the source file.

---

`depend_on_asset` allows you to state an asset dependency without including it.

This is used for caching purposes. Any changes that would invalidate the dependency asset will invalidate the source file. Unlike `depend_on`, this will include recursively include the target asset's dependencies.
 Released in v3.2.0

It appears there are two conflicting approaches to importing Sass in Bower-land.
1. All asset files are expected in main, imports are configured ([grunt-bower-task](https://github.com/curist/grunt-bower), [grunt-bower](https://github.com/yatskevich/grunt-bower-task)). 
2. All the asset files found in main are `imported` by default, exceptions / overrides are configured. The entire bower package is searched in by default, so partials etc do not need to be included, only the main entry points ([wiredep](https://github.com/taptapship/wiredep))

Bower does not specify how `main` should work for a prepocessor at all. I am not sure if either approach is "better", perhaps it would great if one was blessed by Bower?

My gut feel is that `main` is not a place to list "all the asset (public) files" as per no. 1, and prefer 2. Because the first approach requires a lot more maintenance to do right, we'll probably want to switch over.

IIRC there was a problem with the old sprockets gem, which defines a custom Sass importer that does not add the current file's directory to the load path. I do not know if this is still a problem. 

The workaround for this here would be messy (and involve exploding a tree of imports into a giant flat list), so the backport looks like a better solution. The official backport fixes this and many other bugs:

``` ruby
gem 'sprockets-rails', '=2.0.0.backport1'
gem 'sprockets', '=2.2.2.backport2'
```

 @marcovtwout

> What is the current reason for doing this differently?
- For a compiled version (`dist`) you should just use twbs/bootstrap: there is nothing to gain from using this repository apart from the potential compatibility issues. 
- Assets are scoped under `assets` for clear separation between the client-side assets and the rest. Non top-level Sass imports are scoped under `bootstrap/` to avoid name clashes with your own Sass files (e.g. _forms.scss) on import. Non-Sass assets are scoped the same way for consistency. 
- `docs` are not included yet. If we generate Sass snippets along with LESS for http://getbootstrap.com, perhaps then we will copy docs here as well.

 I changed @import to use paths relative to the file in order to avoid relying on modified Sass load path, since the file directory is [always present in @import path](https://github.com/nex3/sass/issues/652#issuecomment-13979922). This is mainly for non-ruby users (e.g. node-sass), as ruby users always get the load path on `require 'bootstrap-sass'`.

This does work out of the box in Rails 4, but, unfortunately, there is a bug in the older versions of the gems that has only been fixed in the backports. Meanwhile, I've added a note on this to Readme.

 Check for where you might be setting `config.assets.initialize_on_precompile = false` as that might make it fall back to non-sprockets assets resolution (I'm guessing you might have set it to false when reading about Rails 3.x on heroku docs). 

Set it back to the default **`true`**

``` ruby
config.assets.initialize_on_precompile = true 
```

Then enable `user-env-compile` for the app on heroku:

``` bash
# Enable precompile support for the app
heroku labs:enable user-env-compile
# Remove precompiled assets
rm -rf public/assets/
git add -u 
git commit -m 'Remove precompiled assets'
# Now push and everything should just work from now on
git push heroku master
```

 I was thinking of versioning issues today. If we have 2.3 archived in a `bootstrap/2.3` folder, we can solve issues with engines like `rails_admin`, which can conditionally include a Bootstrap version based off our defined version number - if the application has b-s 3 installed then rails_admin would include bootstrap/2.3/bootstrap, else it would use the previously defined bootstrap/bootstrap.

Of course, if rails_admin upgrades to b-s 3 then anyone wanting to stop on < 3 is kinda SOL, unless they choose to use static files.

  `width: auto; height: auto;` _are_ the defaults. That is what CSS defines as the default values of width and height, so they should not cause problems. The reset.css _should_ not overwrite any other values, since it will be defined at the HTML level prior to any document or custom CSS is loaded.

It may be `max-width: 100%;` that's messing up. Try adding `max-width: auto;` instead.

You may also want to try the solution proposed of loading isotope in `window.load` instead of `document.ready`

  @barmstrong - I had the same problem. 2.2.2 did NOT fix dropdowns on mobile. It's really this pull that will fix it if merged: twitter/bootstrap#6488

Here's a temporary workaround that worked for me. Place this in your JS after the bootstrap JS is loaded:

``` javascript
  // Temp Fix: Remove after Bootstrap does the right thing and removes touchstart (see issue https://github.com/twitter/bootstrap/issues/6488)
  $('a.dropdown-toggle, .dropdown-menu, .dropdown-menu a, .dropdown-menu .dropdown-submenu a').on('touchstart.dropdown.data-api', function (e) {
    e.stopPropagation();
  });
```

Once a fix is (hopefully) in the next version, we'll pull it in from upstream.

 Maybe I was confused, this was a while back. Let me dig up some artefacts here...

Basically our use of absolute paths (correctly, [here](https://github.com/thomas-mcdonald/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/vendor/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/bootstrap.scss)) should all just work since /vendor/assets/stylesheets _should_ be added as a load path by default, you are correct.

I studied Sass' importer a lot while debugging the above (which turned out to be a non-issue, but anyway). [See relevant source here](https://github.com/nex3/sass/blob/stable/lib/sass/tree/import_node.rb#L47). My conclusion is that imports are only found by **relative** path below the directory of _the originally compiled sass file_ (if for some reason someone imports our bootstrap from `/assets/stylesheets/subdirectory/styles.scss` then only **absolute** imports under `/*/stylesheets/subdirectory/` will be found. This is expected and the reason we changed to absolute paths in the first place (see #258), though somewhat counter-intuitive (one would think that relative imports would also be found under load_paths, but this is in fact not true, only absolute paths can be used under `load_paths`).

With this pull, I simply noticed this new feature of Sass 3 (`Sass.load_paths`) to allow libraries to specify load_paths directly.

[The documentation](http://sass-lang.com/docs/yardoc/Sass.html#load_paths-class_method) says "This is meant for plugins and libraries to register the paths to their Sass stylesheets to that they may be @imported." Basically, it's designed exactly for our purpose, and solidifies our absolute import paths no matter what the parent application sets in its configuration. You can see the original issue that added it had a similar request: nex3/sass#131

So it's not entirely necessary as long as the framework includes the correct `load_paths`, but it's proper for us to do this and ensures it will work no matter what. I think that's a good thing.
 Proof of the absolute vs. relative quirk: try this out in a rails console.

``` ruby
Sass.load_paths << "/full/path/to/bootstrap-sass/gem/vendor/assets/stylesheets"
Sass::Engine.for_file("app/assets/stylesheets/youroriginalsass.scss", {}).options[:load_paths].last.send(:find, 'variables.scss', {})
# nil
Sass::Engine.for_file("app/assets/stylesheets/youroriginalsass.scss", {}).options[:load_paths].last.send(:find, 'bootstrap/variables.scss', {})
# Sass::Engine for variables.scss....
```

So relative paths still have the issue of being based at the directory of the originally compiled .scss file, and `load_paths` paths (added by either the framework or by us) are absolute only. Pretty quirky and not well documented, but it works as long as we have a correct `load_paths` entry.

I have to say, it's not easy to determine how sass treats imports. But my conclusion from debugging these paths yesterday is that it attempts to find a relative path from the directory of the top-level compiled .sass file first, and then an absolute path underneath the `load_paths` config variable. (See [source](https://github.com/nex3/sass/blob/stable/lib/sass/tree/import_node.rb#L44) of the `@import` parser node)

If you're working outside rails, you should add your root CSS path to `load_paths` and it will find the absolute path.

Unfortunately, sass does not use relative paths relative to the current file being processed (as CSS does!), but only relative to the initially compiled file—AKA the one you originally called `@import "bootstrap"` from.

This is unfortunate, because using a relative path works in more cases to find the correct file by name, but it causes other issues: since the original import could be anywhere in the filesystem, using relative paths is not reliable.

Hence, I settled on absolute because I believe it will be more reliable, but I'm open to discussion.

So, you should be able to add a load_path and make this work. Try something like this untested snippet:

``` ruby
(Sass::Plugin.options[:load_paths] ||= []) << "#{YOUR_PROJECT_ROOT}/bootstrap-sass/vendor/assets/stylesheets"
```

More info: apparently [sass-rails considers this a 'feature.'](https://github.com/rails/sass-rails/issues/82) (also describes the behavior quite well). Personally I'd much prefer it to behave like CSS does and always be relative to the current file, but maybe that's just me.

``` ruby
Sass::Engine::DEFAULT_OPTIONS[:load_paths].tap do |load_paths|
  load_paths << File.expand_path "../../bootstrap-sass/vendor/assets/stylesheets", __FILE__ 
end
```

(Adjust the relative path to be from wherever that initializer is stored)

  Thanks for the patch!

Reading through the sass [source code for the import node in sass](https://github.com/nex3/sass/blob/stable/lib/sass/tree/import_node.rb#L47), looks like sass is actually doing something interesting here. First it searches for relative references under the root directory, which is the directory of the original .scss file being compiled. Next, it searches the `load_paths` for an absolute path (the assets/stylesheets directory is one by default, which makes sense). So here we're actually changing this to an absolute reference by making that 2nd condition work (since no file is found using the relative search).

It broke when importing bootstrap from a scss file in a subdirectory because the relative path isn't found under the dirname of the original file, and the absolute path isn't found (because it's under the /bootstrap subdirectory).

So your version is more correct and better because it uses absolute paths. I think this is a good thing as it will be less error prone, and because our files are always at the same location under the gem's vendor/assets/stylesheets folder. 

[Side note: I was confused because this does not match the behavior of CSS itself, which uses the same `@import` syntax, but always respects paths relative to the current file. The `@import` in SASS is a different directive with a different implementation and behavior. In many ways SASS' `@import` is smarter since it will actually attempt to find a filename (with no directory prefix) in any subdirectory of the current folder and even handles conflicts if multiple files are found. Anyway, I digress :) ]

  Yep, sprockets-sass' `image_url` is calling our `image_path`, but we intend to use compass'  separately defined `image_url` in `image_path`, so it goes into an infinite loop. This is an incompatibility with sprockets-sass and compass when used together with bootstrap-sass.

We're basically taking the opposite strategy that sprokets-sass is using and calling `image_url` directly with the path_only option (2nd argument true); meanwhile they're relying on their own `image_path` to return a path-only version of the url.

  I've converted bootstrap-sass to use sass-twitter-bootstrap here, while updating it to the latest version. This pull provides Bootstrap 2.2.1 as currently ported by jlong/sass-twitter-bootstrap@a95350ca4d and a script to efficiently and quickly update the sass-twitter-bootstrap code into the bootstrap-sass gem (I did this mostly as an experiment, so I'm open to using, say, a submodule instead, but this will work as a highly functional proof-of-concept).

I've modified the paths slightly in order to better match sass-twitter-bootstrap's layout, but generally it was a straight copy. The steps (as outlined in the update script) are basically:
1. Remove old `stylesheets/` directory
2. Copy `lib/*` => `stylesheets/`
3. Copy `js/*` => `javascripts/`
4. Copy `img/*` => `images/`
5. Patch `_variables.scss` to use `asset-path` instead of relative paths.

Requires `sass >= 3.2` of course. Updated the gemspec.

Just so you are aware, bootstrap's `variables.scss` file uses `!default` for all variables, which means "set this variable only if it hasn't already been set." Because of that, any variables you define prior to importing bootstrap will be preserved and used.

In other words, you could just do:

``` css
@import "my_app/variables"
@import "bootstrap"
@import "my_app/custom_css"
```

and the result would be exactly the same. Hope this is helpful, and if there's something I'm missing please let me know.

Ok, I think this is very clean after the latest commits above.
- New `/bootstrap` subdirectory (under `vendor/assets/stylesheets`) & move all bootstrap css files there.

  > Sorry, just realized that even more explicit instructions are needed. If the file containing the @import statement is loaded based on the default //= require_tree . in application.css, then the file must be named so that it precedes all other files alphabetically. If it's named bootstrap_loader.css.scss and I have an apples.css.scss file containing custom CSS, the CSS in apples.css.scss will be clobbered by bootstrap.

I think that, in general, if you're using Sass w/Rails, it's better to have a `application.css.scss` file that uses `@import` to require exactly the files you want to load, or to explicitly define the files you want to load (using `//require x`), and in which order.

Having said that, the Readme isn't exactly clear wrt. require specifications. I'll see what I can cook up for 2.0.2.

 So I created a new Rails 3.2.1 application, added RubyProf either side of [internal_precompile](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/master/actionpack/lib/sprockets/assets.rake#L33) and did two runs:

```
rake assets:precompile:primary
rake assets:precompile
```

assets:precompile:primary runs by default in development environment since I didn't change the environment using RAILS_ENV. assets:precompile invokes assets:precompile:all with this command:

```
 /Users/tom/.rvm/rubies/ruby-1.9.3-p0/bin/ruby /Users/tom/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.3-p0/bin/rake assets:precompile:all RAILS_ENV=production RAILS_GROUPS=assets
```

which in turn invokes assets:precompile:primary

My profiling runaround has led me to this piece of lovely code [here](https://github.com/nex3/sass/blob/master/lib/sass/tree/comment_node.rb#L72):

``` ruby
def normalize_indentation(str)
  pre = str.split("\n").inject(str[/^[ \t]*/].split("")) do |pre, line|
    line[/^[ \t]*/].split("").zip(pre).inject([]) do |arr, (a, b)|
      break arr if a != b
      arr + [a]
    end
  end.join
  str.gsub(/^#{pre}/, '')
end
```

in which it would appear almost 100 seconds are spent in production, compared to < 1 in development. Naturally, this has left me wondering why, and I'm struggling to answer that.

Since we have repurposed this ticket somewhat I think we should move the discussion about architecture etc. into #26.
  While a solely-mixin powered Bootstrap would be interesting, I don't think it's something that I would merge back into this gem.

As I see it, Bootstrap is a tool to rapid development, and over time much of the Bootstrap _layout_ styling should be merged into your other SCSS files through the use of the mixins currently used to generate those 'rapid development' classes.

For other things, such as the growing design pattern library (buttons, pagination etc.) I see no problem with these remaining as classes.

If you were to convert Bootstrap to be entirely mixins, that changes the emphasis from rapid development to hand picking. You lose the benefit of being able to quickly use the grid since you have to consider in your CSS which column mixins you are including, rather than tweaking a couple of numbers inside your HTML classes. Although this is arguably a more considered approach, it's substantially different to what I feel Bootstrap should be: a rapid development tool.

So yes, I think it's interesting, but I don't think it will live as part of bootstrap-sass. Feel free to work as a fork of the project, however.

``` ruby
  s.files = Dir["vendor/**/*.css.scss"] + Dir["vendor/**/*.js"] + ["README.md", "LICENSE", "lib/bootstrap-sass.rb", "lib/bootstrap-sass/config/sass-ie_hex_str.rb"]
```

Did the trick.

  The files stay in the location the gem was installed in, and the containing folders are added to your Rails asset load path, meaning they are separate from your application.

Perhaps the quickest way of discovering this would be to open up a Rails console and type the following:

```
Rails.application.config.assets.paths
```

which will return an array of all the folders on your asset load path. This will then let you find the location of the bootstrap-sass gem - which, on my laptop, is in:

```
 "/Users/tom/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.3-p0/gems/bootstrap-sass-1.4.0/vendor/assets/stylesheets"
```

I solved my original problem yesterday with a hack. Because I am using warble/tomcat/jruby stack putting the override code in a scss was failing, that's why while it was looking for it with the hash necessary it was looking for it in the wrong path. So I added this partial (_glyphicons.html.haml) to my haml layout: ``` haml :css @font-face { font-family: 'Glyphicons Halflings'; src: url(#{asset_path 'glyphicons-halflings-regular.eot'}); src: url(#{asset_path 'glyphicons-halflings-regular.eot?#iefix'}) format('embedded-opentype'), url(#{asset_path 'glyphicons-halflings-regular.woff'}) format('woff'), url(#{asset_path 'glyphicons-halflings-regular.ttf'}) format('truetype'), url(#{asset_path 'glyphicons-halflings-regular.svg#glyphicons-halflingsregular'}) format('svg'); } ``` Then I put the fonts in a directory in assets like I say above and changed the config settings (as on previous posts) so it gets precompiled as an asset. This hack allowed it load no problem. And I figured the reason it was failing inside the scss file was that when it compiles the assets (in my dev machine) there is no tomcat container so it assumes there isn't one, while putting it in a haml file allows it to be dynamically generated from the .war file'd application running in tomcat. There is a bug from a change in the bootstrap gem that changes the way the fonts are fetched. I've no hit upon what's causing it. But I am suspecting that it has to do with `@import` settings somewhere. However, my original problem was to why the _override_ wasn't working when it should. One of the recommendations I got was to precompile from the production environment which would not have an effect on my override since the problem was due to when the code was being executed. Hello, I am sorry if this is a misunderstanding on my side but is there any reason why the default path for the icon-font is specified as ``` //** Load fonts from this directory. $icon-font-path: "bootstrap/" !default; ``` and not ``` $icon-font-path: "../fonts/bootstrap/" !default; ``` When I compile the bootstrap.scss with sass and include the css in my html via ``` ``` the glyphicons (which reside in bootstrap-sass-twbs/assets/fonts/bootstrap) are consequently **not** referenced by the bootstrap.css correctly as the output looks like this: ``` @font-face { font-family: 'Glyphicons Halflings'; src: url("bootstrap/glyphicons-halflings-regular.eot"); ... ``` and not like this ``` @font-face { font-family: 'Glyphicons Halflings'; src: url("../fonts/bootstrap/glyphicons-halflings-regular.eot"); ... ``` Using the compiled distribution version of bootstrap, the css references the fonts in a correct relative way (`../fonts/glyphicons-halflings-regular.eot`) and looking at the less code in https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/blob/master/less/variables.less the variable is set to `@icon-font-path: "../fonts/"` So shouldn't the sass ported version not also be set to something like `../fonts/bootstrap/`? Thanks @felixhayashi is correct that the less code in twbs/bootstrap [has the default value](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/blob/v3.2.0/less/variables.less#L76) `@icon-font-path: "../fonts/";`. The current default here at bootstrap-sass, `"bootstrap/"`, fails to work out-of-the-box when you use Sass. There are ways around this issue, for instance, use Compass instead of Sass: 1) Follow [these instructions](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass#b-compass-without-rails) to get started with installing Compass. Make sure you're using the latest version of Compass. 2) Go into config.rb, and uncomment the following line (included by default if you start a new Compass project per the instructions at the link above): ``` ruby # To enable relative paths to assets via compass helper functions. Uncomment: # relative_assets = true ``` 3) Make sure you're importing bootstrap-compass [per these instructions](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass#fonts). Yet it would definitely make more sense to have this work correctly in Sass out-of-the-box, without needing to rely on Compass's URL helpers. Pull request #662 fixes this! Original `less` bootstrap 3.1.1: https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/blob/v3.1.1/less/forms.less#L191-L202 ``` less .radio, .checkbox { display: block; min-height: @line-height-computed; // clear the floating input if there is no label text margin-top: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; padding-left: 20px; label { display: inline; font-weight: normal; cursor: pointer; } } ``` bootstrap sass 3.1.1+2 https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/v3.1.1%2B2/vendor/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/_forms.scss#L207-L220 ``` scss .radio, .checkbox { display: block; min-height: $line-height-computed; // clear the floating input if there is no label text margin-top: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; label { padding-left: 20px; margin-bottom: 0; font-weight: normal; cursor: pointer; } } ``` Please note that in original bootstrap, there is a `padding-left: 20px` applying to `.radio, .checkbox`. But in bootstrap-sass, that padding-left has been moved down to apply only to the inner `label`, to apply to a label inside a `.radio` or `.checkbox`, instead of to any `.radio, .checkbox`. Active progress bars are not animating in my Rails 4 app with bootstrap-sass 3.1.1.1. Downgrading to 3.1.1.0 fixes the issue. My code: ```
``` Having this same issue. Seems to be fixed by adding: ``` @-webkit-keyframes progress-bar-stripes { from { background-position: 40px 0; } to { background-position: 0 0; } } @keyframes progress-bar-stripes { from { background-position: 40px 0; } to { background-position: 0 0; } } ``` But not in Firefox - the progress bars don't even seem to be striped there. +1 ``` @-webkit-keyframes progress-bar-stripes { from { background-position: 0 0; } to { background-position: 40px 0; } } @-moz-keyframes progress-bar-stripes { from { background-position: 0 0; } to { background-position: 40px 0; } } ``` Just added that code at the bottom of my css to override what bootsass was trying to do and it worked. https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/5e583f0219dc6195e3fc5910e053716c06b523ea/vendor/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/_progress-bars.scss So that doesn't seem to work in Firefox, as the stripes in progress-striped don't even show. The reason for this seems to be that something in rails/sass/bootstrap-sass is stripping the "-gradient" part of "linear-gradient" without browser prefixes. So for example, `background-image: linear-gradient(45deg` becomes `background-image: linear(45deg` after processing by the asset pipeline. I was able to fix using the bourbon gem and adding this code: ``` .progress-striped .progress-bar { @include background-image(linear-gradient(45deg, rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.15) 25%, transparent 25%, transparent 50%, rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.15) 50%, rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.15) 75%, transparent 75%, transparent)); } ``` But I'm not sure how to fix this in the bootstrap-sass gem overall. Just to reiterate, the final, complete fix using the Bourbon gem is to add: ``` @include keyframes(progress-bar-stripes) { from { background-position: 40px 0; } to { background-position: 0 0; } } .progress-striped .progress-bar { @include background-image(linear-gradient(45deg, rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.15) 25%, transparent 25%, transparent 50%, rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.15) 50%, rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.15) 75%, transparent 75%, transparent)); } ``` Frustratingly just adding the resultant CSS doesn't work as "-gradient" is stripped from the non-vendor-prefixed "linear-gradient". I'm not sure what's causing that to get stripped though, if anyone has ideas they'd be much appreciated. I think this issue occurred when Bootstrap started to manage vendor prefixes with autoprefixer. https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/commit/cb7eb674accd24b6b73f26ef23cf4a301b6ebfaf#diff-263cb0d16954573b23bf1cc8c2a14e2cL9 Since bootstrap is going to deprecate vendor prefix mixins from less, I think bootstrap-sass gem will eventually need vendor prefixer... +1 having this also.. downgrading to 3.1.1.0 doesn't work for me +1 Running into this as well. Using the 3.1.1 package from bower. Requires users to uncomment the whole variable chain when customizing Bootstrap. This PR tries to address #613. Looks like the build failure is unrelated to the commit. Assume a newly compass + bootstrap-sass project: ``` $ compass create my-new-project -r bootstrap-sass --using bootstrap ``` This produces the following directory structure (bootstrap-sass 3.1.1.1): ``` my-new-project ├── config.rb ├── fonts │   └── bootstrap │   └── ... ├── javascripts │   └── ... ├── sass │   ├── _variables.scss │   └── styles.scss └── stylesheets └── styles.css ``` The documentation says > This will create a new Compass project with the following files in it: > > `_bootstrap-variables.scss` - all of bootstrap variables (override them here). > `styles.scss` - main project SCSS file, import `variables` and `bootstrap`. Well first, the file that compass created is called `_variables.scss`, and not `_bootstrap-variables.scss` but I believe this changed recently. Then the `_variables.scss` files tells you: > // Override Bootstrap variables here (defaults from bootstrap-sass v3.1.1.1) It says **override**. And leaves the content of the file fully commented. This gives the impression you can e.g. tweak a single color variable. So let's pretend you want to tweak `$gray-light` and change it to `red`: you just have a single line to change right? Well it's broken, because Bootstrap defines other variables to `$gray-light`, e.g. [`$headings-small-color`](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/vendor/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/_variables.scss#L834). **So at the point you decide to change `$gray-light` to `red`, `$headings-small-color` is already `#999999` :(** You can reproduce the behavior with this simple `bug.scss` file: ``` @import 'bootstrap/variables'; // very first line of sass/_variables.scss $gray-light: red; // it's as if I only changed this line in sass/_variables.scss // pretend rest of sass/_variables.scss is commented out // as it's the case with a newly created compass project // it's worth noting that bootstrap/_variables.scss defines: // $headings-small-color: $gray-light !default; // and the corresponding line is sass/_variables.scss is commented out body { color: $headings-small-color; // what color do you expect? // nope it's not going to be red // but #999999, the default one :( } ``` I don't know which solution to recommend. Maybe it's les surprising if `sass/_variables.scss` doesn't [`@import "bootstrap/variables";`](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/templates/project/_bootstrap-variables.sass.erb#L1). Choosing this solution means you have to override/uncomment the whole variable chain when customizing variables. Thoughts? I love how this was supposed to be a ultra-minor point release, still based on bootstrap 3.1.1, but a bug fix to the sass implementation. Yet TONS of stuff changed / broke. Tried SASS and bootstrap-sass the first time and also got this error, very frustrating, as a newbie to SASS i have no idea what i can do now. @gpakosz In `sass/_variables.scss`, the variables are defined with the `!default` flag, which means that if they are already defined, they won't be defined again (i.e. not overridden). This means that if you override your variables _before_ `sass/_variables.scss` is imported, it should work just fine. @elmertoft I'm not sure you understood what I'm after. The problem really is that the generated `my-new-project/sass/_variables.scss` starts with `@import "bootstrap/variables"` and as you're mentioning variables are defined with `!default`: > which means that if they are already defined, they won't be defined again. This is the point. They are not already defined when `@import "bootstrap/variables"` kicks in. So they take a default value. Uncommenting/tweaking variable definitions in that generated `my-new-project/sass/_variables.scss` has unexpected effects as I explained. The unexpected effects are caused by "variable chaining" like [`$headings-small-color: $gray-light !default`](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/vendor/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/_variables.scss#L834). If you uncomment and tweak `$gray-light: red;` in `my-new-project/sass/_variables.scss` then it's too late for `$headings-small-color` which already took the default gray value. That's why I'm suggesting the generated `my-new-project/sass/_variables.scss` should not start with `@import "bootstrap/variables"`. Keeping that first `@import "bootstrap/variables"` line will confuse beginner or users switching from Less to SASS. No doubt. @gpakosz Ok, now I follow what you mean :-) I agree with you that the `@import "bootstrap/variables"` line should be removed from the `my_new_project/sass/_variables.scss` file, as per your pull-request (https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/pull/614). That should solve the issue completely, since `@import "bootstrap/variables"` is on line 2 in `~/your_path/bootstrap-sass-3.1.1.1/vendor/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap.scss` which gets imported by the `@import "bootstrap"` that comes _after_ `@import "variables"` in `my_new_project/sass/styles.scss`. I think the readme also needs to be updated with an explanation on how the `!default` flag works. Hi @glebm, I've changed the dependency to bootstrap (instead of the bootstrap-sass): bower.json ``` { "dependencies": { "jquery": "~2.1.1", "jquery-ujs": "*", "bootstrap": "~3.1.1", } } ``` and overrided the path for the fonts: application.scss: ``` //= depend_on_asset "bootstrap/dist/fonts/glyphicons-halflings-regular.eot" //= depend_on_asset "bootstrap/dist/fonts/glyphicons-halflings-regular.woff" //= depend_on_asset "bootstrap/dist/fonts/glyphicons-halflings-regular.ttf" //= depend_on_asset "bootstrap/dist/fonts/glyphicons-halflings-regular.svg" /* *= require_self *= require_tree . */ @import "bootstrap/dist/css/bootstrap"; /* Override Bootstrap 3 font locations */ @font-face { font-family: 'Glyphicons Halflings'; src: url(font-path('bootstrap/dist/fonts/glyphicons-halflings-regular.eot')); src: url(font-path('bootstrap/dist/fonts/glyphicons-halflings-regular.eot?#iefix')) format('embedded-opentype'), url(font-path('bootstrap/dist/fonts/glyphicons-halflings-regular.woff')) format('woff'), url(font-path('bootstrap/dist/fonts/glyphicons-halflings-regular.ttf')) format('truetype'), url(font-path('bootstrap/dist/fonts/glyphicons-halflings-regular.svg#glyphicons_halflingsregular')) format('svg'); } ``` and now everything is working properly. The only (minor) problem is that, apparently, the browser is requesting the old path and the new path: ![screen shot 2014-06-19 at 7 12 18 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/361140/3326788/dbb340b0-f7a2-11e3-91c1-04ac2bfe9ad0.png) However, the fonts are shown properly in all browsers - and this is what's matters most. :) Anyway, thank you so much for your help. The file above isn't usable outside of the environment of this repository, so I simply added the individual files to the `main` array. Is there a way (eg. using sass variables) so I can use sass gem but prevent glyphicon from being loaded there, but from the official cdn instead? `//netdna.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/3.0.0/css/bootstrap-glyphicons.css` Thanks I think you could set the variable `$icon-font-path` to netdna.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/3.0.0/css/bootstrap-glyphicons.css I think it auto prefixes the // consider that there are some cross domain issues with web fonts: http://davidwalsh.name/cdn-fonts So, is this ticket resolved/closeable? Here's how I did it at the end, though it is still quite a workaround. I duplicated the file `https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap.scss` on my project locally (in `assets/bootstrap/boostrap-custom.css.scss`). Then uncommented the lines I did not need, including glyphicon one: `// @import "bootstrap/glyphicons";` and in `application.css`, I load `@import 'bootstrap/bootstrap-custom';` instead of `// @import 'bootstrap';` Since I'm using this gem in version 3.2 (`gem 'bootstrap-sass', '~> 3.2'`), and there is **no official** Glyphicon CDN in version 3.2 and there **are** new icons that are in 3.2 but not in 3.0, I ended up putting a minified version of the glyphicon.css part of bootstrap in a S3 bucket, with CORS policies and behind a cloudfront CDN. Strictly speaking, the ticket can be closed. :smile: > there is no official Glyphicon CDN in version 3.2 Erm, BootstrapCDN.com continues to be the endorsed CDN, and it has Glyphicons files for Bootstrap v3.2.0. In March, I quite deeply searched for it but could not find it. Not a CDN with the whole Bootstrap files, but only with the Glyphicon ones. At 3.0.0 it was there: `//netdna.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/3.0.0/css/bootstrap-glyphicons.css` Ah, you meant the Glyphicons **CSS**. Yeah, there's indeed no separate CDN file for that. Currently, the compile task always creates a `tmp/` directory, even if another directory is specified. The specified directory was also not created if necessary. This PR changes the task so that it creates a specified directory (or the `tmp/` directory) first, then compiles the css into it. Thanks~ ![screen shot 2014-03-16 at 7 55 38 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/874215/2432677/37c7c76e-ad6f-11e3-8cc5-66545c2ff89d.png) The project I'm currently working on has an src/views directory, where a PHP file for each view of my site is located (e.g. services.php, gallery.php, staff.php, etc.) and an src/common directory with things like navigation.php, footer.php, etc. The src/index.php file builds a single site page upon every request to the server, based on what some mod_rewrite rules in an .htaccess file feed it with as $view & $lang query string arguments. So, what pertains to your question, each view file is a wholly contained site module that allows me to build up my site in a pretty scalable way. As such, each of them has a corresponding SCSS stylesheet file in src/styles, all of them using a bower-installed bootstrap-sass. Being modular themselves, too, each stylesheet leverages inclusion of other "library" sylesheets to eliminate redundancy. I have an src/stylesheets/_common.scss partial that does the following: 1) Imports a site-wide variables-override stylesheet where I customize any bootstrap setting I want (src/stylesheets/_varaibles.scss): ``` @import "variables"; ``` 2) Imports bootstrap-sass itself and bootstrap-theme: ``` @import "bootstrap-sass/vendor/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap"; @import "bootstrap-sass/vendor/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/theme"; ``` 3) And finally, and as its name implies, defines the styling for the elements that are common to all site views, like precisely the navigation bar and the footer. E.g.: ``` .navbar { blah; blah; } .footer { foo; bar; } ``` Then each view style, e.g. services.scss, brings bootstrap-sass in, and the rest of the common styling of course, by way of a very simple import of the common partial: ``` @import "common"; ``` Then, of course, each view stylesheet is free to do its own styling of its view elements without affecting any other view in any possible way. Finally, the entire site style for a given view is included into the HTML by the view itself through a commonplace link tag: ``` ``` The HTML head does no separate inclusion of navigation styling, footer styling or any other, since all of those end up being included in each view CSS after stylesheet compilation. This may seem redundant at first ("why repeat navigation and footer styling in each view stylesheet?") but actually it's quite the opposite, since every request to the server produces a page containing at most a single site view through PHP inclusion. A positive side-effect of this is that on every request, the browser will only download the CSS necessary to render the specified view, and nothing else. The actual compilation & minification of the stylesheets, which is what produces the wholly contained CSS files, is taken care of by a Gruntfile I built based on yeoman's webapp generator, which is a great place to start; I highly recommend you take a good look at it if you haven't yet. In short, you're gonna need the contrib-compass and usemin gruntjs plugins to get started, among many others. All in all, I feel this is a pretty good modular approach that allows me to scale my site project horizontally through view "packages"/modules that I can add at any time without affecting the rest of the site in any way, including the existing views. All the while I also get to leverage bootstrap-sass, modernizr, bower, gruntjs, and all of these other new & great front-end dev technologies that are making webdev exciting again. Hope that helps you to get moving in the right direction! @twbs/sass Can someone either give a response or close this as out-of-scope? https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/vendor/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/_variables.scss#L532 The `fadein` method does not exist in Sass, so this results in a string assignment (like "fadein(rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2), 5%)"). The [opacify](http://sass-lang.com/documentation/Sass/Script/Functions.html#opacify-instance_method) method has similar functionality, but takes a value between 0 and 1 instead of a percent. It seems like `rgba($popover-border-color, 0.25);` produces a similar effect. @glebm What about fade_in or opacify? http://sass-lang.com/documentation/Sass/Script/Functions.html#opacify-instance_method I'm pretty sure this is actually broken (see [my comment](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/commit/df7be4f0412497e22f1d271d94d6e9835f61113e#commitcomment-6164044)). I'll submit a pull request to fix it, and look at the functions that @guigs mentions. Yeah, my current hack function is this ``` scss @function fadein($colour, $pct) { @return opacify($colour, $pct / 100); } ``` You can add that to your sheet before Bootstrap is imported if you are using 3.1.1 I've submitted a pull request to hopefully fix this: #600. version: bootstrap-sass (3.1.1.0) If I set `$modal-inner-padding` in my variables.scss, for example, to `9px 15px`, like this: ``` css $modal-title-padding: 9px 15px; ``` the generated css looks like this: ``` css .modal-footer { margin-top: 15px; padding: 9px 15px-1 9px 15px 9px 15px; ``` to make it more clear, if I set to `"9px 15px"`, the output is this: ``` css .modal-footer { margin-top: 15px; padding: "9px 15px"-1 "9px 15px" "9px 15px"; ``` even weirder: `.modal-body` and `.modal-footer` are basically identical and it doesn't work just for the footer: https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/vendor/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/_modals.scss#L94-L101 @glebm awesome. If there are JS and/or CSS files you want to add to the precompile list, the instructions in [the README](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/57bbed7e6f8043ca05c3df36f0d41cc3211876b8/README.md#rails-32x) are inefficient. If you want them to initialize bootstrap-sass on precompile, that does not require them to initialize ALL engines, so they should not use `initialize_on_precompile = true`. Instead, you should instruct them to put the following in `config/application.rb` right after ending the `if defined?(Bundler)` block: ``` module BootstrapInitializer class Railtie < Rails::Railtie initializer :bootstrap_initializer, :group => :assets do require "bootstrap-sass" end end end ``` See [this Stackoverflow example](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9235292/how-can-i-run-some-initializers-when-doing-a-rails-assetsprecompile), that addresses basically this exact issue. This all assumes that you want bootstrap to be initialized on precompile for reasons other than adding non-JS/CSS assets to the precompile list. [Bootstrap's initalizer](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass/blob/57bbed7e6f8043ca05c3df36f0d41cc3211876b8/lib/bootstrap-sass/engine.rb) doesn't include any JS or CSS assets, and according to [Rails' `config/application.rb`](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/v3.2.0/railties/lib/rails/generators/rails/app/templates/config/environments/production.rb.tt) (since Rails 3.1.0), "application.js, application.css, and all non-JS/CSS are already added", so I am very curious why this is necessary at all. There is a cost savings to initialize_on_precompile being false (and, if I understand correctly, you can choose that in Rails4 too, it's just not the default). Depending on what you're initializing, this cost savings could be substantial (it is in my case). Thanks for clarifying which file is the one that we need to load during precompile. So would it be enough to load that file in an initializer that's defined in config/application.rb? Or must we `require bootstrap-sass` so `that BootstrapSass.load!` is called? Either way, I strongly urge you to clarify that in the README as an alternative to setting `initialize_on_recompile = true`. Thanks. Can you just clarify one thing? Why can't this gem be in the assets group in my Gemfile? Incorrect. `rake assets:precompile` automatically sets a RAILS_GROUPS=assets env variable ([here](https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/v3.2.17/actionpack/lib/sprockets/assets.rake#L7)). See https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/3-2-stable/railties/lib/rails.rb#L93 for the effect that has on `Rails.groups` in the line of code you quoted. That's the whole reason the assets group exists--so that it's included in production, test and precompile but not in production. Thanks for this awesome gem. Grids have a percentage for their width and also specify padding. This causes the total width of the grid to be larger than expected. For the three `has-` classes (success, warning, error), the function call is currently using the `-text` color variable in the first two passes, but I believe the second should be the `-border` color variable. This would seem to be a correct fix based on the variable definitions in `mixins.scss` on line 857. As it exists now (`forms.scss` line 272) ``` .has-success { @include form-control-validation($state-success-text, $state-success-text, $state-success-bg); } .has-warning { @include form-control-validation($state-warning-text, $state-warning-text, $state-warning-bg); } .has-error { @include form-control-validation($state-danger-text, $state-danger-text, $state-danger-bg); } ``` Suggested change: ``` .has-success { @include form-control-validation($state-success-text, $state-success-border, $state-success-bg); } .has-warning { @include form-control-validation($state-warning-text, $state-warning-border, $state-warning-bg); } .has-error { @include form-control-validation($state-danger-text, $state-danger-border, $state-danger-bg); } ``` Thanks for supporting SASS! Was linking to http://github.com/thomas-mcdonald/bootstrap-sass, which now redirects to https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass Often, I want to mark something for screen-readers-only, but only at small screen sizes -- at large screen sizes, there's enough room for the thing, but at small sizes I want to hide it -- except not hidden from screen-readers, even at small-sizes. I suspect this is not an unusual desire? Bootstrap provides the `.sr-only` class for hiding things from visible screens but providing them still to screen-readers. However, [because of the way SASS works](http://designshack.net/articles/css/sass-and-media-queries-what-you-can-and-cant-do/), you can't really do an `@extend .sr-only` inside a media query, and have it work properly. So I end up having to just copy-and-paste the .sr-only definition where I want it inside a media query, very un-DRY. (or into my own SASS mixin, an improvement, but still a copy of the original) I think this limitation isn't really the same in the original LESS. But for the SASS version, it would be very helpful if .sr-only were provided as a SASS mixin instead of just a class, so you could `@include` it inside media queries, when you want things to become sr-only at small sizes. I don't understand enough about how the bootstrap-sass build process works to submit a pull request sorry -- I'm not sure whether it's possible to make the build process convert .sr-only in the LESS to a mixin in SASS, or how to do it. But I suggest it might be a good idea? Right, but the workaround would be making a mixin corresponding the .sr-only class, since SASS does support the equivalent with mixins. If Bootstrap were natively SASS, I'd be filing an issue for Bootstrap main branch saying "It would be useful if you would expose .sr-only as a mixin, not just a class, so it could be used in this way in SASS." Since Bootstrap starts out in LESS and is converted to SASS, I am filing an issue here saying "It would be useful if, upon conversion to SASS, you converted this to a mixin instead of just a class, so it could be used this way in SASS." But okay, I understand you are not interested in that at this time, so it goes! (SASS does kind of support extend inside media querries -- it just doesn't do what you might want it to do, and would want it to do in this case.) I'm leaning toward the first option. The problem is that according to [SemVer](http://semver.org/) any version number with a dash + characters at the end is considered prerelease > A pre-release version MAY be denoted by appending a hyphen and a series of dot separated identifiers immediately following the patch version. Identifiers MUST comprise only ASCII alphanumerics and hyphen [0-9A-Za-z-]. Identifiers MUST NOT be empty. Numeric identifiers MUST NOT include leading zeroes. Pre-release versions have a lower precedence than the associated normal version. A pre-release version indicates that the version is unstable and might not satisfy the intended compatibility requirements as denoted by its associated normal version. Examples: 1.0.0-alpha, 1.0.0-alpha.1, 1.0.0-0.3.7, 1.0.0-x.7.z.92. @glebm Thanks for jumping on that so quickly. Alas, that didn't seem to fix it though. But, I have good news! The Composer website states : > This idea is not new and Composer is strongly inspired by node's npm and ruby's bundler. But there has not been such a tool for PHP. Clearly saying it's meant to be NPM and Rubygem's equivalent for PHP. I'm not saying Composer _can't_ do it, I'm saying your using the wrong tool for the job. Bower isn't the _only_ tool for that but at least it's made for that, you can use Component too, or Jam, or [whatever other front-end package manager there is](https://github.com/wilmoore/frontend-packagers), but I don't see the need to try to make Composer do everything because it's not its purpose. Not to mention if really you **do** absolutely want to have one and only package manager file in your project you can easily do so via the `repositories` entry : ``` json "require": { "twbs/bootstrap-sass": "version" }, "repositories": [ { "type": "vcs", "url": "https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap-sass" } ] ``` Without having to register it on Packagist where it's out of place. Composer can't ignore files from the build to make packages lighter to install, Composer has no notion of main JS or CSS file, etc. Composer has nothing for front-end packages while Bower has all these features, because that's _not_ its job. In the light of that I really don't see why anyone would want to use Composer for that. Surely the fact that its core is a **PHP classes autoloader** should mean something no ? There's a degree of convenience that Packagist/Composer provides with little cost on this end (although it sounds like several people believe otherwise). For better or worse, many people browse/search Packagist for tools they can deploy quickly without a lot of hassle. In short, I'm happy to depend on the latest bootstrap always, with a few minor customizations I hold in _variables.scss and bootstrap.scss I don't know if this answers the question about using bootstrap-sass in a non-ruby context, but what I do is simply install bootstrap-sass (sudo gem install bootstrap-sass, which may or may not pull in the compass gem dependency, don't quite recall) and then simply "init" my project with bootstrap-sass through compass, as indicated in the documentation: compass create my-new-project -r bootstrap-sass --using bootstrap Once that's done, my new project has a config.rb file that tells compass where to put the products, and all I need to do is run "compass watch &" only once before I start seeing my CSS files get recompiled each time I change their scss sources (the & in the above command sends the job to the background, where it lurks without bothering me until I decide to stop it). On iterating through the bootstrap assets **alerts.scss** is the first scss it comes across. However this scss does not include the **variables.scss** (for all declared variables) for compilation since it may not have been intended to compile down as a separate css. you might want to change the **config.assets.precompile** to add additional files. It would be great if you add a valid bower.json file to this repo! bootstrap-sass only works with ruby for now, but that should change soon https://github.com/thomas-mcdonald/bootstrap-sass/pull/473 @AlJohri @glebm Bower is actually looking at this repo's tags to generate the available version numbers. Unfortunately, when the tags changed to add an additional dot-number, i.e. the `vN.N.N.N` format rather than `vN.N.N`, it broke the way Bower parses them. So `v2.0.3` is the last available version that Bower sees. The ideal fix would be to simply change the version tags to something [semver](http://semver.org/), which is what Bower prefers. Then you wouldn't even need a manifest file. It would just work. Good points, and good question. What about a new, additional tag that follows semver, but is intended only for Bower consumption? E.g. something like `v3.0.2-bower`. Perhaps `v3.0.2-bower.1`, `v3.0.2-bower.2` to capture that last `.N` somehow. (The importance [and formatting] of that is debatable, IMO.) It's also worth noting that a user can just force-install a specific tag/SHA like so: ``` bower install '#' ``` (This solved the issue for me.) I think it's a question for @glebm, et. all, how important Bower support is vs. the extra effort it will take to implement an additional tagging scheme and/or create & maintain a package file. I don't really know if it's 'fixing' semver, given we're not following it. Thanks! :smile: If you try to `File.read` from the erb template, then it will use the relative path from where you're parsing the template, not the relative path from the repo. Because the file that needs to be created isn't there yet (obviously), it throws an error of `File not found`. So copying the file from the relative path needs to happen in the manifest. Relevant bit of Compass Extensions documentation: > ERB Processing - This can be used to customize the contents of the file in an extension template. **The template will be processed in the context of a TemplateContext instance**, which gives you access to the full project configuration information as well as the command line options. Since it's unlikely many templates will need this functionality, I leave it as an exercise of the user to figure it out and if they can't to contact the compass-devs mailing list for assistance. Hi, a simple Mixin for multiple transitions is missing. It is not possible to use: ``` sass @include scale(1.25); @include rotate(120deg); ``` on the same time. Possible solution would be: ``` sass @mixin transform($transform) { -webkit-transform: $transform; -moz-transform: $transform; -ms-transform: $transform; -o-transform: $transform; transform: $transform; } ``` and can be used by: ``` sass @include transform(scale(1.25) rotate(120deg)); ``` What are the differences between this repo and [jlong/sass-twitter-bootstrap](https://github.com/jlong/sass-twitter-bootstrap)? Keeping bootstrap-sass in sync with upsteam changes from Bootstrap is an error prone and time consuming manual process. This pull request is specifically concerned with automating that process as much as possible to allow a much faster release cycle. Upstream changes to the Twitter Bootstrap project can now be pulled in using the `convert` rake task. Here's an example run that would pull down the `3.0.0-wip` branch from the official twitter/bootstrap repo: ``` % bundle exec rake 'convert[3.0.0-wip]' ``` The latest converter script is located [here](https://github.com/intridea/bootstrap-sass/blob/3.0.0-wip/tasks/converter.rb) and does the following: - Converts upsteam bootstrap Less files to its matching Scss file. - Namespaces mixin names with `twbs-` prefix to avoid conflicts with other libs. - Copies all upstream javascripts into `vendor/assets/javascripts/bootstrap` - Generates a javascript manifest at `vendor/assets/javascripts/bootstrap.js` - Copies all upstream font files into `vendor/assets/fonts` This less to scss conversion is pretty good, but not perfect. So manual fixes to the resulting Scss will necessary for now. The current version has only been tested with the official twitter/bootstrap `3.0.0-wip` branch. See [these github issues](https://github.com/intridea/bootstrap-sass/issues?labels=converter&state=open) tagged with `conversion` which track the current shortcomings of the conversion process. Cheers for the work on this. It looks very cool, but I imagine I'm not going to be able to go through this properly until next Friday at the earliest due to exams. First thought though (having glanced at the changelog) is that I hate the idea of `twbs-` prefixing everything, mostly because although (I guess, having never really used other mixin libraries) it will stop conflicts, it's going to make using the Boostrap mixins an absolute pain in the arse, and it breaks from our philosophy thus far of being as close to the less files as we can get. Sure @thomas-mcdonald. I did try and keep the prefix as short as possible, and `twbs` is the name of the soon-to-be migrated Github org account for bootstrap. (see: http://blog.getbootstrap.com/2012/12/10/bootstrap-3-plans). So while I understand your prefix reluctance, my reasoning comes from the fact that you already made bootstrap-sass work so nicely with compass (as pointed out in the [readme](https://github.com/thomas-mcdonald/bootstrap-sass#compass)). However, if you use it with compass you're already conflicting with multiple out of the box [compass mixins](http://compass-style.org/reference/compass) without even knowing it. I also believe you'd conflict with [Bourbon](http://bourbon.io) mixins if you use that. Also, my understanding is that Bootstrap 3 is going to allow the option to use minimal styling (or flat UI). So using other sass libraries will probably be much more useful in the future. And I'd prefer to use 3rd party mixins for additional UI customization since many are designed better, and it will help prevent sites from looking like all the other bootstrap sites out there. If you still disagree, I guess it would be pretty easy to remove the prefixes from the PR. But I think the minimal effort of adding a prefix is much less painful than having to maintain a separate fork to avoid conflicting with other libs. Thanks for the update! Given BS comes with mixins like `vertical-gradient`, it's nice that they are prefixed, but any library that relies on Bootstrap LESS mixins will be a bit harder to convert to use bootstrap-sass. If we want prefixes it would be better to raise an issue in twbs. @glebm Part of the problem is that Sass ans Less are not analogous with respect to how you use mixins. First of all, in Less you can overload mixins names by defining the same mixin with different arguments. So the chance of getting a conflict is reduced. Second, it's easier to define namespaced mixins in Less by doing something like: ``` .twbs { .vertical-gradient() {...} .horizontal-gradient() {...} } ``` So while I agree that it would be nice if bootstrap itself would namespace their mixins in this way, it's probably never going to happen. That's because LESS does not have as much of a community of 3rd party mixin libaries (aside from bootstrap iteslf). So if you're using LESS, you're probably only using bootstrap mixins. But for the sake of forward progress, I can move the prefixing out into another pull request so that it can be discussed in greater detail. Would that be helpful @thomas-mcdonald? Fixes #366 Fallback to old method of accessing the context object, and use the correct access method through the `:importer` key of the `options` hash, which is set on the context by Sass. The context is passed into the Engine (which is a Tilt::Template) and used as the _scope_ of the render method (see here: https://github.com/rtomayko/tilt/blob/master/lib/tilt/template.rb#L92) , which calls `evaluate(scope...)`. This is how the Sass engine gets access to the options hash to begin with, and how the options hash has the scope of the Context. If you want to follow, look for how Engines are defined in Sprockets `sprockets.rb`, file types have engines defined by extension in `asset_attributes.rb`, which are then called in `context.rb` -- https://github.com/sstephenson/sprockets/blob/master/lib/sprockets/context.rb#L194 (that's where the scope is passed into the engine, and the context passed with it). The `importer` is added to the options hash when the import is parsed, by the `Sass::Importers::Filesystem` (which `Sprockets::SassImporter` extends) here: https://github.com/nex3/sass/blob/stable/lib/sass/importers/filesystem.rb#L181 In other words, this should be the correct way, and the context of the importer will always be the Sprockets context if used within Sprockets. Whew. The new way is of course preferable since Sprockets > 2.10 adds a nice `:sprockets` hash to the options hash directly, so it's still worth it to use that if it exists. (line 65, 66 and 67). https://github.com/twitter/bootstrap/commit/86bb3b8126c94ee8c839eac4d9120f3edeafefdd Regarding the note in the Readme about Semver: if you use build version syntax (2.3.1+1), you'll be compatible with Semver, and preserve honesty in versioning. I don't think I'm following you - if Bootstrap changes y or z (minor or patch versions), and we need to release multiple versions on top of that to address any problems, adding a +version will allow us to do so within the constraints of Semver. The part of the version string that breaks Semver is the third dot delimiter. I'm only suggesting that we use a Semver-accepted delimiter before our "patch" version. First, I want to acknowledge that the + character doesn't do what I intended, because build metadata is supposed to be ignored in version precedence. The - character is a better fit (the pre-release designator). Both are not truly semantic, but appending our versioning onto another version system isn't exactly semantic anyhow. Currently, sass-twitter-bootstrap has tags that look like 2.2.0.1 and 2.3.0.1. That's not legal in Semver, so it fails when used as a Bower component, for example. I'm suggesting that the version strings be 2.2.0-1 and 2.3.0-1. We'd follow Bootstrap's version numbers, continue to append our own versions as appropriate, but do so without breaking Semver. I'm more concerned with the letter of the law than its spirit (though both matter). If Twitter breaks the rules of Semver by changing the public API on a minor or patch version, there's not much we can do about that. However, we can control whether our versions actually validate as Semver or not, and that's what I'm recommending. Glad to see a 3.0 branch! Where did _reset.scss go? Two major changes: 1. Improve the load logic to take into account that Sprockets might be used without Rails. Simplify and DRY it up. It should have exactly the same effect as before, with the exception that `rails_functions.rb` is now only loaded if ::Rails is defined. 2. Improve the `image_path` sass function to delegate to the Sprockets `image_path` directly if Sprockets is available. This is a near-direct copy of sprockets-sass' version here: https://github.com/petebrowne/sprockets-sass/blob/master/lib/sprockets/sass/functions.rb#L62 This covers Rails and Sprockets usage, while the next condition for Compass continues to cover Compass-only use. This fixes #257 - SystemStackError infinite loop when bootstrap-sass is included with Sprockets but not Rails. Overall this pull should make bootstrap-sass work with non-Rails installations that use Sprockets. I have also tested with our Rails app and all continues to work great, since the new `image_path` function is equivalent to the one sprockets-sass provides. There should be no conflict. I also made a quick Sprockets-Sass-Compass Rack (man that's a lot of buzzwords) test app here. Twitter Bootstrap is essentially setting this css: img { width: auto\9; height: auto; } What CSS can I add after this to undo this? If I comment out the CSS in the gem source, my issue is resolved, but that doesn't help me when the gem is loaded by heroku. So I need a local override/monkey patch to fix this. Thanks. Here is the issue: https://github.com/desandro/isotope/issues/335#issuecomment-11507013 and here: https://github.com/twitter/bootstrap/issues/6541 The problem without this patch is that the awesome isotope library can't function properly as chrome and safari can't draw the images correctly. I posted the answer here: https://github.com/twitter/bootstrap/issues/6541 Inlining this in the CSS worked, like this: img src="blah-blah" width=398 height=265 style="width:398px; height:265px" In fact, I also tested Isotope without using the width and height attributes, like this: img src="blah-blah" style="width:398px; height:265px" And that worked fine! Any recommendation if it's better to only specify the CSS? I was able to very easily test this without bootstrap (or bootstrap 2.0) by using this CSS: img { width: auto; height: auto; } It seems that the width and height in the CSS do override the image properties, and before the images get loaded, the browser does not know how much space to allocate, and then, even after the images load, the spacing is still wrong, at least with Isotope. Inlining the style does workaround the issue. I think I tried using regular styles, but that didn't seem to work, but I may have had a CSS priority issue. Any way, since the image size is laid out with the image properties, it's rather natural to put in this tiny bit of inline CSS. I hope we eventually find a better solution, as this will surely affect others when upgrading. Or at least this should be documented that one needs to use the inline style for the width and height of the image rather than the properties. I have some modal windows in my Rails project. I can confirm renaming that file solved my issues This is a Rails generator I wrote that makes it easy to include a Twitter Bootstrap template as a layout file. The templates are copied from [the examples](http://twitter.github.com/bootstrap/getting-started.html#examples) and modified to use the Rails asset pipeline. **Syntax** ``` rails g bootstrap_sass:layout application --template=fluid ``` **From the USAGE file** ``` Description: Generates a layout based on the Twitter Bootstrap example templates. **Note:** The layout doesn't include <%%= yield %>. You will need to add that yourself. The template choices are - starter_template (default) - hero - fluid Example: rails generate bootstrap_sass:layout application --template=fluid This will create: app/views/layouts/[LAYOUT_NAME].html.erb ``` **Note:** This pull request doesn't include tests. I'm not familiar with TestUnit and I wasn't sure how to write tests for a rails generator. +1 +1 Curious if any additional thought has gone into this. Would love to have this added. Just curious, what's the reason to skip the `<%= yield %>`? It would be very useful (at least to me) to be able to prefix all of the classes provided by Bootstrap, to more clearly distinguish them from my sites' own classes and those provided by other tools. Class names like `row` are far too generic; something like `tb-row` would be much clearer. Unfortunately, [this idea has been rejected upstream](https://github.com/twitter/bootstrap/issues/1287#issuecomment-3690546), so I'm submitting it here instead. I'd be happy to submit a pull request with this change if you're interested. I'm mostly scratching my own itch, but I'm also hoping that it will help to advocate for the issue to be reconsidered upstream. Implementation-wise, this: ``` scss .pagination { } .pagination ul { } .pagination ul > li { } ``` Would simply become: ``` scss .#{$tbPrefix}pagination { } .#{$tbPrefix}pagination ul { } .#{$tbPrefix}pagination ul > li { } ``` Configuration-wise, I'd add an (empty by default) `$tbPrefix` variable to the top of `_bootstrap.scss`, which can be set in my app's stylesheet before importing Bootstrap. Let me know what you think. Dropdown compatibility for mobile devices, as per https://github.com/twitter/bootstrap/issues/4550#issuecomment-8684262 Fair enough. Mobile dropdown functionality is pretty important to my site, so I thought others might be interested in the same. It seems Sass doesn't support `fadein` method... It supports [fade_in](http://sass-lang.com/docs/yardoc/Sass/Script/Functions.html#opacify-instance_method), so I changed `fadein` to `fade_in`. I would really appreciate it if you took a look. "box-shadow" mixin should allow multiple shadows as Compass built-in mixin (http://compass-style.org/reference/compass/css3/box_shadow/#mixin-box-shadow) and CSS3 Standars (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/CSS/box-shadow). This way you will allow Compass to compile without problems. Right now I'm getting the following error: "Syntax error: Mixin box-shadow takes 1 argument but 2 were passed." I'm not speaking for the author, but this gem is billed as a 1:1 conversion from LESS to SASS, so this may be somewhat of a design decision to exclude Compass as a dependency. That being said, I feel your pain. This seems to be the best Bootstrap sass conversion (there are many) but I really like Compass, and I want the best of both worlds. So what I do, is copy the bootstrap files from the `vendor/assets/stylesheets` dir into my project. Then in `mixins.scss`, I just comment out `border-radius` and `box-shadow`. Assuming you've already imported `compass/css3`, this should compile without problems. There are better ways to do this but I generally use Compass in a non-Rails atmosphere, so this works for me. This way works as well, proving that it really doesn't matter where it is included, as long as it's included. ``` css /* *= require_self *= require _bootstrap *= require _bootstrap-responsive *= require_tree . */ @import 'font-awesome'; ``` You should be using `@import 'bootstrap'` and `@import 'boostrap-responsive'` in a .scss file, see the Rails [Asset Pipeline Guide](http://guides.rubyonrails.org/asset_pipeline.html#manifest-files-and-directives). There are differences between official Bootstrap and booststrap-sass for progress bars : https://github.com/thomas-mcdonald/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/vendor/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/_progress-bars.scss#L54 ``` css .progress .bar { width: 0%; height: 18px; color: $white; font-size: 12px; text-align: center; text-shadow: 0 -1px 0 rgba(0,0,0,.25); @include gradient-vertical(#149bdf, #0480be); @include box-shadow(inset 0 -1px 0 rgba(0,0,0,.15)); @include box-sizing(border-box); @include transition(width .6s ease); } ``` https://github.com/twitter/bootstrap/blob/master/less/progress-bars.less#L55 ``` css .progress .bar { width: 0%; height: 100%; color: @white; float: left; font-size: 12px; text-align: center; text-shadow: 0 -1px 0 rgba(0,0,0,.25); #gradient > .vertical(#149bdf, #0480be); .box-shadow(inset 0 -1px 0 rgba(0,0,0,.15)); .box-sizing(border-box); .transition(width .6s ease); } ``` Differences are : - `height` (not very problematic) - `float: left` missing => This miss makes stacked progress bars unusable since they are stacked vertically instead of horizontally. Load path: C:/Projects/App: ``` Just upgraded to bootstrap-sass 2.0.3. My static navbar, when displayed in collapsed (responsive) mode, was showing up as 47 pixels high instead of 40. Also the brand text was no longer centered vertically. I tracked this back to the `.navbar .btn` element in `_navbar.scss`. The vertical margin of the collapse button is calculated based on the `$elementHeight`. Twitter Bootstrap uses uses 28px; bootstrap-sass uses 20px: https://github.com/twitter/bootstrap/blob/b261f9781bbf31f499cb55c49451dc0c0ad43062/less/navbar.less#L220 https://github.com/thomas-mcdonald/bootstrap-sass/blob/master/vendor/assets/stylesheets/bootstrap/_navbar.scss#L200 I changed the bootstrap-sass `_navbar.scss` version on my machine to use 28px for the `$elementHeight` and the navbar is once again displaying correctly. Confirmed fixed. Working sample with patched version: http://nezabudem.net/obelisks/29/photos/5 (left-top grey button) have you tried changing the `$btnBackground` and `$btnBackgroundHighlight` colors? Especially changing the `$btnBackgroundHighlight` to be something other than a 10% darker version of `$btnBackground`. For example, set `$btnBackground` to be `#fff` and `$btnBackgroundHighlight` to be `#09f`. That should give you a white to blue gradient for the normal button state, but if the `.btn:hover` background color is just 10% darkened white, you'll have a nasty gray creeping in below the blue as the `background-position` slides up `15px`. The mechanics of it are that there is a `background-image` as a CSS generated gradient from `$btnBackground` _down_ to `$btnBackgroundHighlight` which initially completely covers the full button. But it is set to repeat only along the x-axis so below it and above it the `background-color` would show through. When a `.btn` is in the `:hover` state, the CSS simply animates the `background-position` _up_ 15 pixels (`background-position: -15px`) thereby moving the CSS gradient _up_ 15 pixels and exposing below it whatever color is set as the `background-color`. That is why I think the `background-color` on `:hover` should be the same exact color as `$btnBackgroundHighlight`. I spend a little too much time googling for this, so I figured others could benefit from having this lil' nugget in the readme. Essentially, passing multiple values (`box-shadow`s, for instance) as a single parameter to Sass mixins, requires you to escape the values to avoid syntax errors caused by the comma(s). Other frameworks, eg. Compass, takes [a different approach](http://compass-style.org/reference/compass/css3/box_shadow/#mixin-box-shadow), using a fixed number of parameters. Mark Otto (@markdotto) wrote about his approach using escaped values in LESS and I think it warrants documentation in this project. (The site was down when I wrote this, here's a cached copy for reference: http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:http://www.markdotto.com/2012/04/05/comma-separated-values-in-less-mixins/) Again, thanks a bunch for your work on this gem!! :heart: I don't understand why this project overwrites the built-in compass helpers. Should the duplicate ones just be escaped? @aaronchi People use bootstrap-sass without using compass. Don't use Sproket's //= require directives for SASS files, because they're horrible and will kill your cat. Why are Sprocket's `//= require` directives horrible? Why do you prefer `@import`? That sentence is not any helpful at all. It is just confusing. Sprockets compiles each file individually, so mixins or variables to set in one file do not work in another; hence, all the mixins and variables available via Bootstrap are not within the scope of your own files, so you can't use them. Import basically imports the files together and then they are compiled, allowing you to override and use Bootstrap. Sorry if this is misinformed; but then doesn't this mean that you lose the performance improvements of only having to recompile the single SASS file that's been changed, when in a development environment? I suspect that not using sprockets (in order to use mixins) is the reason I have to wait ~2-3 seconds each time I want to recompile my CSS. EDIT: Aha! Think I found a really nice solution; instead of having to `@import "bootstrap";` in every scss file, I'm just doing that in my main.scss and then doing; ``` css @import "bootstrap/variables"; @import "bootstrap/mixins"; ``` whenever I need mixins in scope.
